messageBody:
Hello,

I've search the archives but I can't find a thread that pertains to the
topic I'd like to discuss. [I am not saying it isn't there, I just couldn't
find it by my search criteria.]

I have a lot of unit tests, I usually run them inside the Eclipse test
runner (that finds all my tests in a project) or the Ant test runner (which
again finds all). As such, I've given up on test suites as unnecessary for
my purposes. [The effort to "wire tests together" is more than I need/want,
and might even limit me from just adding new tests whenever needed.] This
"test suite" part may be unimportant, or not...

I write unit tests for the low level objects, and also for the higher level
aggregating objects that use them. This helps me track down the cause of
high level failures much easier. When junit detects problems and things fail
I get a (sometimes long) list of failures. Finding the "root cause" problem
means sifting through all the failures (including the aggregating failures)
in order to find the problem, perhaps down in a low level class test. Since
I can't control the order of execution (it is likely package alphabetical or
something), I can't tell what is the lowest level test. I'd like to reduce
the effort invested here.

I was wondering if jUnit could introduce the concept of "optional test
dependencies", test X depends upon Y -- i.e. test Y runs before test X, and
test X runs IFF test Y succeeds.

I wouldn't want to do this for every test, and it ought be user optional,
but I could see it as being a big benefit. I am sure there is some fancier
OO way to explain/implement this [or even a nicer introspection way to
determine this], but something like a TestCase.setDependency(Class
testClass) so TestCase constructors mark what they'd like to depend upon.
[For introspection maybe a public Class[] getDependencies()
interface/method].

The test runner engine would need to "sort" the calling order be dependency
tree, and would need to know when not to call something, perhaps introducing
a new state ("deferred" -- meaning not run due to a dependency
failure/error -- to add to "fail", "error".)

I know this is some work, but it seems (to me, at least) a simple yet
powerful addition to jUnit. [That said, maybe I am missing something, such
as test suites or something. Hmm ... maybe this dependency information could
be used to create anonymous suites on the fly...]

Thoughts?

regards,

Adam

P.S. The Eclipse junit plugin that search projects to find all tests, find
tests in dependant project, but doesn't run them "in the CWD of that
project" (which matters for some tests). This considered a bug, or just the
way it is? I know of no way to have the search exclude dependent projects,
is there one?
